title: Warring Senate and House Republicans see peacemaker in Ryan
authors: Burgess Everett, John Bresnahan, Jake Sherman, Kevin Robillard
content:
Senate Republicans who ’ ve been sparring all year with their counterparts in the House suddenly see a silver lining : the Ryan Reset .
The expected ascension of Rep. Paul Ryan to House speaker offers the GOP a fresh start after flailing attempts at coordination and bombs thrown all year long between the two chambers under Republican control .
Ryan is said to be much more comfortable with setting expectations about what the Senate can realistically accomplish than was House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy , who annoyed the Senate GOP with suggestions that Majority Leader Mitch McConnell change Senate rules to make it easier to overrun Democrats .
GOP senators are expecting a very different attitude from the conservative but pragmatic Ryan ( R-Wis. ) .
“ This will be an opportunity for us to try to refresh the relationship , ” said Sen . Rob Portman ( R-Ohio ) , who spent countless hours alongside Ryan during his vice presidential run in 2012 . “ The fact is we have a different system over here , and Paul gets that . I think he ’ ll be very effective communicating that to his colleagues . ”
The House ’ s latest shot at the Senate came in the form of a debt ceiling proposal loaded with conservative goodies , including a proposal that would stifle the Senate minority ’ s ability to filibuster spending bills . While House Republicans have since ditched that plan , it is emblematic of the turbulence of the first Congress fully under GOP control since the Bush administration .
The two chambers have been at odds again and again . First the House tried to use a homeland security spending bill to nix President Barack Obama ’ s immigration policy , a strategy rejected by McConnell . A dispute between the two chambers over surveillance reform caused a law used to track terrorists to lapse for two days . And in July , House Speaker John Boehner ( R-Ohio ) called a transportation bill proposed by McConnell ( R-Ky. ) a “ piece of sh -- . ”
Now Republicans in both chambers are struggling mightily to raise the debt ceiling in a manner that can appease fiscal conservatives . A House call to Dr. Ryan might be just what this tumultuous relationship needs .
“ He has a lot of friends over here as a result of his presidential campaign and the work on budget negotiations and all that , ” said Sen. John McCain ( R-Ariz. ) . “ It will probably be an improvement . ”
One thing Ryan will have trouble doing is corralling the House conservatives who seem to relish tweaking senators as gutless appeasers of Democrats . Rep. Mick Mulvaney ( R-S.C. ) , who loathes McConnell ’ s tactics and strategy , laughed for 10 seconds when he was asked whether Ryan would help ease antagonism toward the Senate and instructed a reporter to “ record that laugh and print that . ”
“ They should expect us to continue to remind folks back home that the Senate is the problem , ” Mulvaney said . “ Mitch McConnell overpromised and underdelivered . And he ’ d better do something about it quick or else he ’ s going to be back in the minority . ”
There has always been tension between the two chambers . Uninhibited by the filibuster , the House majority can run roughshod over the minority and jam through as much legislation as it wants ; the Senate runs at a pace as languid as an August day and empowers individual members to muck up the best-laid plans .
Republicans from both chambers held a rare joint retreat last winter to help set expectations based on those fundamental differences . While Sen. Harry Reid ( D-Nev. ) was blamed as the choke point between the House ’ s legislation and Obama ’ s desk , the reality is that the Senate ’ s rules play a big part , too .
Often , House members have a revelation about the Senate ’ s limitations only if they become senators themselves .
“ That ’ s just baked into the cake . You just have a little bit of institutional rivalry , ” said Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn ( R-Texas ) . “ Maybe this will give us an opportunity to unify . I think that ’ s the single most important thing : When we ’ re divided , we basically default to the opposition . ”
Senate Democrats are also intrigued by Ryan ’ s speakership given his work on a major bipartisan budget deal in 2013 with Sen. Patty Murray ( D-Wash. ) . For all their attacks on his budget-slashing reputation , Democrats believe that Ryan ’ s broad backing by Republicans in both chambers gives him more room to run than Boehner has had in years .
“ He wants our country to function , and I respect him for that , ” Murray said .
If Ryan can return some sense of normalcy to the House , it could hurt Democratic efforts to use the GOP disarray as a weapon in next year ’ s elections . Reid and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi ( D-Calif. ) have been arguing for months that one-party control of Congress has been a mess , with the threat of government shutdowns and debt defaults constantly hanging over Washington .
“ To the extent that Paul helps us develop better strategy , better messaging and stuff , that would be helpful . What happens or doesn ’ t happen here [ in the Capitol ] could certainly influence my race , ” said Sen. Ron Johnson of Wisconsin , one of the most endangered Republicans in 2016 . “ I ’ d say he ’ s going to be a positive influence on my race . ”
Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee Chairman Jon Tester of Montana said he had no intention of using Republicans ’ support for Ryan ’ s budget and its reforms to Medicare as a main point of attack in 2016 .
Top Republican aides are cautioning against looking to Ryan as a savior . For one thing , they said that the nine-year leadership relationship between McConnell and Boehner basically worked well , and there ’ s no guarantee that will be replicated by Ryan and his staff .
Plus , the fundamental balance of power in Congress isn ’ t going to be changed by Ryan . The Senate is still going to need at least six Democratic votes to clear filibusters , and House Republicans are still going to get mad about it .
Ryan “ should give the Senate some confidence that maybe the relationship can get better , ” said Rep. Reid Ribble ( R-Wis. ) . The three-term congressman then paused to give the Senate some marching orders on overhauling the filibuster so Republicans can more easily pass their agenda . It was exactly the kind of advice from House members that senators have chafed at .
“ Now , there ’ s some things obviously they can fix over there … if they don ’ t want to be the punching bag that they ’ ve been , ” Ribble said . “ The American people would embrace it . ”

Harry Reid (D-Nev.) was blamed as the choke point between the House’s legislation and Obama’s desk, the reality is that the Senate’s rules play a big part, too.

Often, House members have a revelation about the Senate’s limitations only if they become senators themselves.
